author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Trump controversies come while Kushner observing Shabbat :report
text:
Jared Kushner, Ivanka Trump and President Trump in 2011. (Jeff Kravitz/FilmMagic) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Tuesday, January 31, 2017, 6:29 PM 
It is “not a coincidence” that some of President Trump’s most controversial moments came when two of his closest advisors was observing the Shabbat, according to a report. 
Trump’s daughter Ivanka and son-in-law Jared Kushner are seen as a moderating force on the commander-in-chief’s policies, though Vanity Fair reports that he has been out of the loop in critical phases. 
The magazine wrote that Kushner and Ivanka, who are Orthodox Jews, do not work or use technology from sundown on Fridays to sundown on Saturdays, which is when Trump complained about reports of his inauguration crowd size. 
“He wasn’t rolling calls on Saturday when this happened,” an unidentified source said. “To me, that’s not a coincidence.” 
Sean Spicer defends White House statement after omitting Jews 
Beyond that Saturday, chaos surrounding Trump’s travel ban, believed to have been pushed by nationalist-leaning advisor Steve Bannon, also occurred during Shabbat. 
Bannon's influence is seen as growing in the administration's first weeks, and the former Breitbart editor has been given a seat on the National Security Council. 
This Saturday also saw the White House release a statement on the Holocaust that did not specifically mention Jews, which gained national attention despite officials' claims that it was being blown out of proportion. Some of Trump's controversial policies are believed to stem from advisor Steve Bannon. (CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS) 
Going back to July 2015, one of Trump’s first controversial campaign statements, saying that Sen. John McCain was “not a war hero” because he was captured. 
White House defends refugee ban, Steve Bannon's spot on NSC 
The Sundays after each of those Saturdays saw Trump’s team more under control. 
Trump followed the McCain statements by pointing out that he did call the senator a war hero in the same interview, and White House officials tried to clarify the executive orders this past Sunday. 
Though Kushner and Ivanka Trump moved to Washington to be closer to her father’s administration, Vanity Fair reports that they are enjoying less and less influence. 
Kushner was reportedly particularly miffed that a meeting he had brokered with Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto fell apart after a tweet from his father-in-law, with one source describing him as “f---ing furious.” Join the Conversation:
